title: Phase 1: Cortex Core — Scheduler + Rate Limiter
description: Working Go binary that reads beads from project dirs, builds dependency graphs, finds unblocked tasks, respects unified rate limits, dispatches openclaw agents, and tracks state in SQLite. This is the core scheduling engine.

title: Main binary entry point + systemd unit
description:
Wire everything together in cmd/cortex/main.go and create the systemd service file.

main.go:
1. Parse flags: --config (default: cortex.toml), --once (run single tick then exit, for testing)
2. Load config via config.Load()
3. Open store via store.Open(config.StateDB)
4. Create rateLimiter, dispatcher, scheduler
5. Start scheduler in goroutine
6. Block on signal (SIGINT/SIGTERM) for graceful shutdown
7. On shutdown: cancel context, wait for running tick to finish, close store

cortex.service (systemd user unit):
  [Unit]
  Description=Cortex Agent Orchestrator
  After=openclaw-gateway.service

  [Service]
  Type=simple
  ExecStart=%h/projects/cortex/cortex --config %h/projects/cortex/cortex.toml
  Restart=always
  RestartSec=10
  Environment=PATH=%h/.local/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin

  [Install]
  WantedBy=default.target

Makefile targets:
  build: go build -o cortex ./cmd/cortex/
  install: cp cortex ~/.local/bin/
  service-install: cp cortex.service ~/.config/systemd/user/ && systemctl --user daemon-reload
  service-start: systemctl --user enable --now cortex.service

Acceptance criteria:
- cortex binary starts, runs one tick with --once flag, exits cleanly
- cortex binary runs continuously and responds to SIGTERM
- systemd unit installs and starts correctly
- Logs appear in journalctl --user -u cortex.service
close_reason: Main binary, systemd unit, and Makefile all implemented

title: TOML config loader

Structs needed:

- CountAuthedUsage5h() -> int
- CountAuthedUsageWeekly() -> int
- RecordHealthEvent(eventType, details)
- RecordTickMetrics(project, open, ready, dispatched, completed, failed, stuck)

Indexes: idx_dispatches_status, idx_dispatches_bead, idx_usage_provider(provider, dispatched_at)

title: Beads CLI wrapper
description:
Implement internal/beads/beads.go that wraps the bd CLI to read bead data from project directories.

Functions:
- ListBeads(beadsDir string) -> []Bead, error
  Runs: bd list --json --quiet in the given directory
  Parses JSON into Bead structs

- ShowBead(beadsDir, beadID string) -> BeadDetail, error
  Runs: bd show --json {beadID}

- CloseBead(beadsDir, beadID string) -> error
  Runs: bd close {beadID}

Bead struct fields:
  ID, Title, Description, Status, Priority, Type, Labels []string,
  EstimateMinutes int, ParentID string, DependsOn []string,
  Acceptance string, Design string, CreatedAt time.Time

BuildDepGraph(beads []Bead) -> *DepGraph
  Builds a directed graph from DependsOn + ParentID edges.
  
FilterUnblockedOpen(graph *DepGraph) -> []Bead
  Returns beads that are: status=open AND all DependsOn beads are closed AND parent is open (not skipped).
  Sorted by: Priority ASC (P0 first), then EstimateMinutes ASC.

Acceptance criteria:
- ListBeads correctly parses bd list --json output
- DepGraph correctly identifies unblocked beads
- Unit tests with sample JSON fixtures (no actual bd calls)
- Handles empty bead lists gracefully

title: Unified rate limiter
description:
Implement internal/dispatch/ratelimit.go with the unified authed rate limiter.

Core concept: All authed subscription providers (Claude Max20, OpenAI Pro, Google Pro, Kimi) share two hard gates — a 5h rolling window cap and a weekly cap. Free-tier providers (cerebras, groq) are uncapped.

Functions:
- NewRateLimiter(store *store.Store, cfg config.RateLimits) -> *RateLimiter
- CanDispatchAuthed() -> (bool, string reason)
  Checks both gates against store.CountAuthedUsage5h() and store.CountAuthedUsageWeekly()
  Returns false + reason if either gate exceeded
- RecordAuthedDispatch(provider, agentID, beadID string)
  Delegates to store.RecordProviderUsage()
- WeeklyUsagePct() -> float64
  Returns current weekly usage as percentage of cap
- IsInHeadroomWarning() -> bool
  Returns true if WeeklyUsagePct >= config.WeeklyHeadroomPct (default 80%)

Algorithm for provider selection within a tier:
- PickProvider(tier string, providers []config.Provider) -> *config.Provider
  1. If tier is fast -> pick from free providers (no quota check)
  2. If tier is balanced/premium -> check CanDispatchAuthed()
  3. If authed gates pass -> return first available provider in tier order
  4. If gates fail -> return nil (caller handles tier downgrade)

Tier downgrade logic (in scheduler, not here):
  premium -> balanced -> fast, or defer to next tick

Acceptance criteria:
- 5h rolling window correctly counts dispatches in last 5 hours
- Weekly rolling window correctly counts dispatches in last 7 days
- Free-tier providers bypass all gates
- Headroom warning triggers at configured percentage
- Unit tests with seeded usage data covering: under cap, at cap, over cap, headroom warning
close_reason: Rate limiter implemented with tests, all passing

title: Role inference + complexity detection
description:
Implement internal/scheduler/role.go and internal/scheduler/complexity.go.

Role inference (role.go):
- InferRole(bead Bead) -> string
  Maps bead labels/type to agent role:
  | Bead Labels / Type | Role |
  | Any open bead with code files listed | coder |
  | Label contains review, test, qa | reviewer |
  | Label contains deploy, ops, ci | ops |
  | Type = epic | skip (Cortex tracks epic completion automatically) |
  | Default | coder |
  
- ResolveAgent(project string, role string) -> string
  Returns '{project}-{role}' (e.g. 'hg-website-coder')
  Falls back to 'main-{role}' if project-specific agent doesn't exist

Complexity detection (complexity.go):
- DetectComplexity(bead Bead) -> string (tier: fast|balanced|premium)
  | Signal | Tier |
  | estimated_minutes <= 30 | fast |
  | estimated_minutes 31-90 | balanced |
  | estimated_minutes > 90 | premium |
  | Label complex or architecture | premium |
  | Label trivial or chore | fast |
  Labels override time-based detection.

Acceptance criteria:
- Role correctly inferred from labels with priority ordering
- Complexity correctly maps estimate + labels to tier
- Label override takes precedence over time estimate
- Unit tests cover all mapping combinations

title: Agent prompt builder

Implement internal/scheduler/prompt.go that constructs the prompt sent to openclaw agents.

Function:

Template:

title: OpenClaw agent dispatcher
description:
Implement internal/dispatch/dispatcher.go that wraps the openclaw CLI to dispatch agents.

Functions:
- Dispatch(agent string, prompt string, provider string, thinkingLevel string) -> (pid int, error)
  Runs: openclaw agent --agent {agent} --message {prompt} --thinking {thinkingLevel}
  Starts process in background, returns PID for tracking.
  thinkingLevel derived from tier: fast=none, balanced=low, premium=high

- IsProcessAlive(pid int) -> bool
  Checks if PID is still running via kill -0

- KillProcess(pid int) -> error
  Sends SIGTERM, waits 5s, then SIGKILL if still alive

Environment setup:
  Ensure openclaw binary is in PATH
  Set CWD to project workspace directory

Acceptance criteria:
- Dispatch starts an openclaw agent process and returns valid PID
- IsProcessAlive correctly reports live/dead processes
- KillProcess terminates gracefully with fallback to SIGKILL
- Unit tests mock exec.Command for isolation
- Integration test (manual): dispatches a real agent with a trivial prompt, confirms PID tracking

title: Core scheduler tick loop
description:
Implement internal/scheduler/scheduler.go — the main orchestration loop that ties everything together.

Scheduler struct holds references to: config, store, rateLimiter, dispatcher, logger.

RunTick() method (called every config.TickInterval):
1. For each enabled project (sorted by priority):
   a. beads = ListBeads(project.BeadsDir)
   b. graph = BuildDepGraph(beads)
   c. ready = FilterUnblockedOpen(graph)
   d. Record tick metrics (beads_open, beads_ready counts)
   
2. For each ready bead (up to maxPerTick across all projects):
   a. Skip if alreadyDispatched (check store.GetRunningDispatches)
   b. role = InferRole(bead) — skip if epic
   c. tier = DetectComplexity(bead)
   d. provider = rateLimiter.PickProvider(tier)
   e. If provider nil: try tier downgrade (premium->balanced->fast), log if all exhausted
   f. prompt = BuildPrompt(bead, project)
   g. agent = ResolveAgent(project.Name, role)
   h. pid = dispatcher.Dispatch(agent, prompt, provider, thinkingLevel)
   i. store.RecordDispatch(bead.ID, project.Name, agent, provider, tier, pid, prompt)
   j. rateLimiter.RecordAuthedDispatch(provider) if authed
   
3. CheckRunningDispatches():
   a. For each running dispatch in store:
   b. If PID dead -> mark completed or failed based on exit code
   c. Record duration

Start() method:
  Runs RunTick in a goroutine on a ticker, respects context cancellation for graceful shutdown.

Acceptance criteria:
- Tick loop iterates projects by priority
- Respects maxPerTick limit across all projects
- Skips already-dispatched beads (no double dispatch)
- Tier downgrade works: premium->balanced->fast
- Running dispatch status polling detects completed/failed
- Integration test: mock all deps, verify dispatch sequence with sample beads
- Structured logging (slog) for each dispatch decision
close_reason: Scheduler tick loop implemented, all tests pass

title: Phase 3: Self-Propelling Pipeline
description: Multi-dispatch per tick (up to max_per_tick=3), auto-advance stuck stage labels, pipeline flush when downstream has 0 tasks but upstream completed, immediate child-unblock detection on bd close.

title: Multi-dispatch per tick
description:
Enhance the scheduler tick loop to dispatch up to max_per_tick (default 3) agents per tick across all projects, rather than just 1.

Changes to scheduler.go RunTick():
1. Collect all ready beads across all enabled projects into a single priority-sorted queue
2. Dispatch up to max_per_tick from that merged queue
3. Respect per-project ordering (higher priority project's beads sort first)
4. If rate limiter blocks authed dispatch, still try free-tier beads from the queue
5. Log: 'Dispatched {n}/{max} this tick, {remaining} ready beads queued'

Also add configurable per-project max_concurrent (default: 2) to prevent one project hogging all slots.

Acceptance criteria:
- Multiple agents dispatched in single tick when beads available
- Per-project concurrent limit respected
- Free-tier dispatches not blocked by authed rate limit exhaustion
- Integration test with multiple projects and beads verifies dispatch ordering

title: Immediate child-unblock detection
description:
When a dispatch completes (detected during CheckRunningDispatches), immediately check if any of the completed bead's children/dependents are now unblocked, rather than waiting for the next tick.

Changes:
1. After marking a dispatch as completed in CheckRunningDispatches():
   a. Get the bead ID that was just closed
   b. Re-run ListBeads + BuildDepGraph for that project
   c. Filter newly unblocked beads (beads whose last blocking dep was the just-completed bead)
   d. If any newly unblocked AND within max_per_tick budget: dispatch immediately
2. Log: 'Bead {id} completed, {n} children now unblocked, dispatching {m}'

This creates a reactive chain: as agents close beads, Cortex immediately picks up the next work without waiting 60s.

Acceptance criteria:
- Completing a bead triggers immediate check for newly unblocked children
- Newly unblocked beads dispatched within same tick cycle
- Still respects rate limits and max_per_tick
- Does not re-dispatch already-running beads
- Unit test: complete parent bead, verify child gets dispatched

title: Pipeline flush for stalled downstreams
description:
Detect when a project's downstream beads have 0 open tasks but upstream beads have been completed, indicating the pipeline has stalled at a stage transition.

Logic:
1. After each tick, for each project:
   a. Group beads by epic/parent
   b. If an epic has all children closed -> auto-close the epic via bd close
   c. If all beads in a dependency chain are closed but the chain's root epic is still open -> close it
2. This prevents epics from staying open forever when all their children are done.

Also handle stage label advancement:
- If a bead has label 'ready' and gets dispatched -> could optionally update label to 'in-progress' via bd CLI
- On completion -> label updated to 'done' (or just bd close handles this)

Acceptance criteria:
- Epics auto-closed when all children are closed
- No false positives (don't close epics with open children)
- Handles nested epics (epic with child epics)
- Unit test with sample bead graphs verifying auto-close logic

title: Scrum master as project point-of-contact via Matrix
description:
Make the scrum master agent the human-facing communication interface for each project, communicating bidirectionally via Matrix.

Currently the scrum master silently refines tasks, and the Reporter sends generic digests through a 'main' agent. These are disconnected. The scrum master should OWN the communication loop for its project:

**Outbound (scrum master → human):**
- Progress reports: what completed, what's in flight, what's blocked
- Blocker alerts: dependencies stuck, agents failing, rate limits hit
- Decision requests: ambiguous tasks needing human judgment
- Stage transition summaries: 'task X moved to review, agent Y picked it up'

**Inbound (human → scrum master):**
- Priority changes: 'drop everything, focus on X'
- Task creation: 'add a bug for the login issue'
- Status queries: 'what's the status of feature Y?'
- Guidance: 'use approach A not B for auth'

**Key design:**
- Each project gets its own Matrix room (or thread)
- The scrum master agent is the only one that talks to humans
- Other agents (coder, reviewer, ops) report TO the scrum master, not directly to Matrix
- Reporter refactored to delegate to scrum masters rather than dispatching directly
- Inbound messages are polled/received and routed to the correct project's scrum master

This turns Cortex from a silent automation engine into something you can actually talk to per-project.

title: Add per-project Matrix room config
description:
Extend cortex.toml and config parser to support per-project Matrix room routing.

Current config only has a global [reporter] section with a single channel and agent_id. Need per-project Matrix targeting so each scrum master talks in its own room.

Config changes:
```toml
[projects.hg-website]
enabled = true
beads_dir = "~/projects/hg-website/.beads"
workspace = "~/projects/hg-website"
priority = 1
matrix_room = "!abc123:matrix.org"   # NEW: project-specific room
```

Also support a default room in [reporter] as fallback:
```toml
[reporter]
channel = "matrix"
agent_id = "main"
default_room = "!general:matrix.org"  # fallback if project has no room
```

Changes to internal/config/config.go:
- Add MatrixRoom string to Project struct
- Add DefaultRoom string to Reporter struct
- Validation: warn (not error) if project has no matrix_room and no default_room
- Helper: ResolveRoom(project) returns project room or default

Acceptance: Config parses with and without matrix_room, ResolveRoom works, backward compatible

title: Give scrum master project state context
description:
Build a project state summarizer that gives the scrum master rich context about its project before it communicates.

Currently when a scrum master agent is dispatched, it only sees the single bead it's refining. To be a useful point of contact, it needs the full picture.

Create internal/scheduler/context.go with:

type ProjectContext struct {
    Project       string
    OpenBeads     int
    InProgress    int
    Blocked       int
    CompletedToday int
    FailedToday   int
    RunningAgents []RunningAgent  // currently dispatched
    RecentCompletions []string    // last 5 completed bead titles
    BlockerSummary    []string    // what's blocked and why
    Velocity          float64     // beads/day rolling 7d
}

type RunningAgent struct {
    Agent    string
    BeadID   string
    BeadTitle string
    Role     string
    Duration time.Duration
}

func BuildProjectContext(store, project) ProjectContext:
- Query store for dispatch stats
- Query beads for open/blocked/in-progress counts
- Calculate velocity from GetProjectVelocity
- List running dispatches with durations

func FormatContextForPrompt(ctx ProjectContext) string:
- Render as markdown section that gets prepended to scrum master prompts
- Concise but complete: '3 open, 1 blocked (X depends on Y), 2 agents running'

Acceptance: Context builds from store data, formats cleanly, tested

title: Refactor Reporter to route through scrum master agents
description:
Change the Reporter to dispatch messages through each project's scrum master agent instead of the generic 'main' agent.

Current flow (internal/learner/reporter.go):
  Reporter.dispatchMessage() → dispatcher.Dispatch(cfg.AgentID='main', message)

New flow:
  Reporter.SendProjectDigest(project) → dispatcher.Dispatch(project+'-scrum', message)
  Reporter.SendProjectAlert(project, type, msg) → dispatcher.Dispatch(project+'-scrum', message)

Key changes:
- SendDigest becomes SendDigests (iterates projects, sends per-project digest)
- Each digest goes through that project's scrum master agent
- The scrum master agent's system prompt (ROLE.md) already positions it as the communicator
- Include ProjectContext in the digest prompt so scrum master has full picture
- The scrum master then formats and sends to Matrix (its agent config points at the project's room)

Fallback: if project has no scrum master agent, fall back to generic 'main' agent

Remove the old single-message-blast pattern. Each project gets its own tailored communication.

Acceptance: Digests route through scrum master, per-project context included, fallback works

title: Implement scrum master outbound notifications
description:
Add event-driven outbound notifications from the scrum master to Matrix, beyond just daily digests.

Notification types (internal/scheduler/notify.go or similar):

1. **Blocker Alert**: When a bead becomes blocked or an agent fails
   - Trigger: dispatch fails, stuck timeout hit, rate limit exhausted
   - Message: 'Task X is blocked: agent failed after 30m, escalating to premium tier'

2. **Stage Transition**: When a bead moves between stages
   - Trigger: stage label changes detected during bead discovery
   - Message: 'Task X moved to review (was: coding). Agent hg-website-reviewer picking it up next tick.'

3. **Decision Request**: When scrum master identifies ambiguity during refinement
   - Trigger: scrum master's refinement output contains a decision flag
   - Message: 'Task X needs clarification: should we use REST or GraphQL for the new endpoint?'

4. **Completion Summary**: When a bead is closed
   - Trigger: bead status changes to closed
   - Message: 'Task X completed by hg-website-coder. 3 files changed, tests passing.'

5. **Capacity Warning**: When rate limits approach headroom
   - Trigger: WeeklyUsagePct > headroom threshold
   - Message: 'Rate limit at 85%. 30 dispatches remaining this week. Prioritize carefully.'

Implementation:
- Create a Notifier that the scheduler calls at appropriate points in RunTick
- Notifier routes through the project's scrum master agent
- Dedup logic (don't spam same alert within 1h, already exists in Reporter)
- Notification preferences per project (optional, can be added later)

Acceptance: All 5 notification types fire at correct triggers, routed through scrum master, deduped

title: Implement Matrix inbound message polling
description:
Add the ability for Cortex to receive inbound messages from humans via Matrix and route them to the correct project's scrum master.

This is the hardest piece — making communication bidirectional.

Create internal/matrix/poller.go:

Approach: Poll Matrix room(s) for new messages using the Matrix client-server API.

type Poller struct {
    homeserver string
    token      string
    rooms      map[string]string // room_id → project name
    since      string           // sync token for incremental polling
    interval   time.Duration
    handler    InboundHandler
}

type InboundMessage struct {
    Project   string
    Room      string
    Sender    string
    Body      string
    Timestamp time.Time
    EventID   string
}

type InboundHandler interface {
    HandleMessage(ctx context.Context, msg InboundMessage) error
}

Flow:
1. Poller runs on interval (e.g. 30s)
2. Calls Matrix /sync endpoint with since token
3. Filters for m.room.message events in tracked rooms
4. Ignores messages from our own bot user
5. Maps room → project
6. Calls handler.HandleMessage() for each new message

Config additions to [reporter] or new [matrix] section:
```toml
[matrix]
homeserver = "https://matrix.org"
token_env = "CORTEX_MATRIX_TOKEN"  # read from env var, never in config
poll_interval = "30s"
bot_user = "@cortex-bot:matrix.org"
```

Security: token read from env var only. Never stored in config file.

Acceptance: Poller connects to Matrix, receives messages, routes to correct project, handles reconnection

title: Implement scrum master inbound command handling
description:
When the scrum master receives an inbound human message via Matrix, it needs to understand and act on it.

Create internal/scheduler/inbound.go:

type InboundProcessor struct {
    store      *store.Store
    dispatcher *dispatch.Dispatcher
    projects   map[string]config.Project
}

func (p *InboundProcessor) HandleMessage(ctx, msg InboundMessage) error:
1. Dispatch to the project's scrum master agent with:
   - The human's message
   - Current ProjectContext
   - Instructions to parse intent and take action
2. The scrum master agent determines what to do:
   - **Status query** → respond with project state summary
   - **Priority change** → run bd update to reprioritize
   - **Task creation** → run bd create with details
   - **Guidance** → update relevant bead's design notes
   - **Other** → acknowledge and note for next standup
3. Scrum master's response goes back to the Matrix room

The scrum master agent handles the NLU — we don't need to parse commands ourselves. The agent's ROLE.md should be updated to include:
- 'When you receive a human message, determine the intent and take the appropriate action'
- 'Always respond in the Matrix room with what you did'
- 'For status queries, use bd list and bd show to gather current state'

Update ROLE.md in internal/team/team.go to add communication responsibilities.

Acceptance: Human messages dispatched to scrum master, scrum master responds with actions, response sent back to Matrix

title: Update scrum master ROLE.md for communication responsibilities
description:
Update the scrum master agent's role description in internal/team/team.go to reflect its new position as the project's point of contact.

Current ROLE.md focuses only on task refinement. Expand to cover:

```markdown
# Scrum Master Agent

You are the scrum master and primary point of contact for this project.

## Communication (Primary)
- You are the ONLY agent that communicates with humans
- Report progress, blockers, and decisions via Matrix
- When you receive a human message, determine intent and act:
  - Status queries: gather state with bd list/show, summarize
  - Priority changes: reprioritize with bd update
  - Task creation: create beads with bd create
  - Guidance: update design notes on relevant beads
  - Always confirm what you did

## Daily Standup
- Summarize: what completed yesterday, what's in progress, any blockers
- Flag beads that have been in_progress for >24h
- Highlight rate limit status if above 70%

## Task Refinement
- Review descriptions for clarity and completeness
- Add or improve acceptance criteria
- Break large tasks into sub-tasks
- Estimate effort when missing

## Stage Workflow
- You receive tasks at stage:backlog
- When refinement is complete, transition to stage:planning
- Always unassign yourself after transitioning
```

Also update EnsureTeam() to re-write ROLE.md if it detects the old version (or add a version marker).

Acceptance: New ROLE.md covers communication, standup, and refinement. Agent behaves as point of contact.

title: Implement scrum master daily standup report
description:
Replace the generic daily digest with a scrum-master-authored standup report per project.

Current digest (Reporter.SendDigest) is a simple template:
  '## Daily Cortex Digest — {date}
   - project: N beads completed today
   - Health: N events'

New standup (dispatched through scrum master agent):
The scrum master receives ProjectContext and produces a standup-style report:

**Yesterday:**
- Completed: list of closed beads with brief outcomes
- Failed: any beads that failed with reasons

**Today:**
- In Progress: what's currently being worked, by which agent
- Ready: what's unblocked and queued for dispatch
- Blocked: what's stuck and on what

**Risks:**
- Rate limit status (usage/cap)
- Stuck dispatches or repeated failures
- Beads in_progress for >24h

The scrum master formats this conversationally, not as raw data. It should feel like a team standup message in a chat room.

Schedule: runs at daily_digest_time from config (default 09:00).
Replaces Reporter.SendDigest() calls — the standup IS the digest.

Acceptance: Standup generates per-project, routed through scrum master, includes all sections, conversational tone

title: Plan pluggable dispatch: headless CLI vs tmux vs openclaw by task complexity
description:
Plan the dispatcher abstraction to support multiple backends based on task characteristics.

## Context
- Current dispatch is tightly coupled to openclaw agent CLI (~5 lines in dispatch.go)
- OpenClaw gateway serves comms and planning, not just agent dispatch — that value must be preserved or replaced
- Headless CLIs (claude, codex, kimi, kilocode) can handle coding tasks directly without a gateway
- tmux gives observability and session persistence for longer/complex work

## Key Design Questions

### 1. Task routing by complexity/length
- **Fast tier (≤30min, trivial/chore)**: headless CLI is ideal — fire and forget, low overhead
- **Balanced tier (31-90min)**: headless CLI or tmux? At what duration does observability matter?
- **Premium tier (>90min, complex/architecture)**: tmux likely better — attach to watch, survives crashes, can interact if stuck
- Should routing be tier-based, estimate-based, or label-based?

### 2. When tmux vs headless
- tmux adds: observability (attach to watch), crash resilience (session persists), ability to interact
- tmux costs: session management complexity, cleanup of dead sessions, port/name collisions
- headless adds: simplicity, easy PID tracking (already implemented), lower overhead
- Decision: what's the threshold? 60min? 'complex' label? premium tier only?

### 3. OpenClaw gateway role
- Gateway currently handles comms (Matrix?) and planning/coordination between agents
- If we move coding dispatch to headless CLIs, gateway still needed for:
  - Inter-agent communication
  - Task planning and decomposition
  - Status reporting
  - Any shared context/memory between agents
- Need to map which gateway functions are essential vs replaceable

### 4. Pluggable dispatcher interface
- Abstract dispatch behind a Go interface: Dispatch(ctx, prompt, workDir, opts) -> (handle, err)
- Backends: headless-cli, tmux, openclaw (keep as option)
- Config in cortex.toml per-provider or per-tier
- Process tracking: PID for headless, session name for tmux, PID for openclaw

### 5. Provider mapping
- Which headless CLIs map to which providers?
  - claude CLI -> claude-max20 (and free tier via different model flag)
  - codex CLI -> openai-pro
  - kimi CLI -> kimi
  - kilocode -> ?
- How do thinking levels translate per CLI?

## Deliverable
Architecture decision doc + implementation plan for the dispatcher refactor.

title: Phase 4: Self-Improving + Reporter
description: Outcome detection (poll bd list for closed beads), duration tracking, weekly retro analysis of dispatches table, tier mismatch flagging, provider weight adjustment. Daily digest and event-driven alerts via Matrix through openclaw agent.

title: Outcome tracking + duration logging
description:
Implement internal/learner/outcomes.go — tracks task completion outcomes for learning.

Functions:
- RecordOutcome(dispatch Dispatch, bead Bead) -> error
  Called when a dispatch transitions to completed or failed.
  Records: bead_id, tier used, provider used, duration_s, exit_code, retries needed, escalated_from_tier.
  
- GetProviderStats(window time.Duration) -> map[string]ProviderStats
  Aggregates per-provider: total dispatches, avg duration, success rate, failure rate.
  
- GetTierAccuracy(window time.Duration) -> map[string]TierAccuracy
  Compares assigned tier vs actual duration:
  - If a 'fast' tier task took >90min -> tier was underestimated
  - If a 'premium' tier task took <30min -> tier was overestimated
  Returns misclassification rate per tier.

- GetProjectVelocity(project string, window time.Duration) -> ProjectVelocity
  Beads completed, avg time per bead, throughput (beads/day).

All data sourced from the dispatches table in store.

Acceptance criteria:
- Outcomes recorded on every dispatch completion
- Provider stats accurately reflect success/failure rates
- Tier accuracy detects misclassifications
- Project velocity calculated correctly
- Unit tests with seeded dispatch data

title: Weekly retrospective analysis
description:
Implement internal/learner/retro.go — generates a weekly retrospective report analyzing Cortex's performance.

Function:
- GenerateWeeklyRetro() -> RetroReport
  Analyzes the past 7 days of dispatches data:
  
  1. Summary stats: total dispatches, completed, failed, stuck, avg duration
  2. Provider performance: per-provider success rate, avg duration, failure modes
  3. Tier accuracy: how often was the tier classification correct vs actual duration
     - Underestimates (fast task took premium time) -> suggest label adjustment
     - Overestimates (premium task was trivial) -> suggest downgrade
  4. Project velocity: beads/day per project, backlog burn rate, ETA to empty
  5. Rate limiter utilization: peak 5h window usage, weekly usage, headroom triggers
  6. Recommendations: auto-generated suggestions like:
     - 'Provider X had 40% failure rate — consider deprioritizing'
     - 'Tier fast is overloaded — raise threshold to 45min'
     - 'Project Y stalled — 0 beads completed in 3 days'

- FormatRetroMarkdown(report RetroReport) -> string
  Formats the report as a clean markdown message suitable for Matrix delivery.

Scheduled: runs on config.Reporter.WeeklyRetroDay (default: Monday).

Acceptance criteria:
- Retro covers all 5 analysis dimensions
- Recommendations are actionable and specific
- Markdown output is clean and readable
- Unit tests with seeded week of dispatch data
- Handles edge case: no dispatches in the past week

title: Daily digest + event-driven Matrix alerts
description:
Implement Matrix integration for Cortex reporting via openclaw agent dispatch.

Daily digest (scheduled at config.Reporter.DailyDigestTime, default 09:00 AEST):
- Dispatches the 'main' agent with a formatted status message:
  ## Daily Cortex Digest — {date}
  - **{project}:** {completed} beads completed, {ready} ready, {running} in progress
  - **Providers:** {provider} {used}/{cap} for each authed provider
  - **Health:** {events_count} events, {restarts} restarts
  - **Next up:** {top_3_ready_beads}

- Command: openclaw agent --agent main --message {digest} --deliver --reply-channel matrix --reply-to {room_id}

Event-driven alerts (immediate, not scheduled):
Cortex sends immediate alerts for:
1. Task failed after max retries -> includes bead ID, error details, retry history
2. Gateway down for >5min -> includes restart attempts, last error
3. Provider weekly quota >80% -> includes current usage, projected depletion

Implementation:
- internal/reporter/reporter.go with Reporter struct
- SendDigest() method for daily digest
- SendAlert(alertType, message) for event-driven alerts
- Both use dispatcher.Dispatch to send via openclaw agent

Acceptance criteria:
- Daily digest sent at configured time with accurate stats
- Event alerts sent immediately on trigger conditions
- Messages formatted as readable markdown
- Does not send duplicate alerts for same event within 1h (dedup)
- Unit tests verify message formatting and dedup logic

title: Multi-workflow support: stage-based pipelines for dev, content, trading
description:
Replace single-shot dispatch with multi-stage workflow pipelines. Each workflow defines ordered stages with stage-specific roles, prompt templates, transition rules, and validation gates. A bead progresses through stages (each stage = a separate dispatch) rather than being handled in one shot.

Target workflows:
- **Dev**: implement → test → review → merge/deploy
- **Content**: research → draft → edit/review → publish
- **Trading**: signal analysis → risk validation → execution → confirmation/audit

Key capabilities:
- Workflow definitions in cortex.toml config
- Workflow engine tracking stage progression per bead
- Stage-aware prompt building with per-stage templates
- New roles beyond coder/reviewer/ops (writer, editor, analyst, executor, etc.)
- DB schema extension for stage tracking (current stage, stage history, stage outputs)
- Automatic workflow assignment based on bead labels/type
- Gates between stages (e.g., tests must pass before review stage)
- Manual override to skip/repeat stages

This is the largest architectural change since initial orchestrator implementation.

title: Define workflow data model and config schema
description:
Design and implement the core data structures for workflows.

A Workflow definition needs:
- Name (string identifier, e.g. 'dev', 'content', 'trading')
- Stages: ordered list of Stage definitions
- Default: bool (is this the fallback workflow?)
- Match rules: labels/types that auto-assign this workflow

A Stage definition needs:
- Name (e.g. 'implement', 'test', 'review')
- Role (agent role for this stage, e.g. 'coder', 'reviewer', 'writer')
- Tier override (optional, force a specific complexity tier)
- Prompt template key (which prompt template to use)
- Gate (optional validation command that must succeed before advancing)
- Auto-advance (bool: advance automatically on completion, or wait?)

Config schema in cortex.toml:
```toml
[workflows.dev]
default = true
match_labels = ["dev", "code", "feature", "bug"]
match_types = ["task", "bug", "feature"]

[[workflows.dev.stages]]
name = "implement"
role = "coder"
prompt_template = "implement"

[[workflows.dev.stages]]
name = "test"
role = "reviewer"
prompt_template = "test"
gate = "go test ./..."

[[workflows.dev.stages]]
name = "review"
role = "reviewer"
prompt_template = "review"
tier = "premium"
```

Create Go types in internal/workflow/types.go

Acceptance: Types compile, config can be parsed from TOML, unit test for parsing

title: Add comprehensive tests for workflow system
description:
Write tests for the entire workflow system.

Test files:
- internal/workflow/types_test.go - config parsing, validation
- internal/workflow/engine_test.go - stage progression, gate handling, completion
- internal/workflow/prompts_test.go - template rendering per stage

Key test scenarios:
- Bead progresses through all stages of dev workflow

- Concurrent beads at different stages

Acceptance: All tests pass, >80% coverage on workflow package

title: Extend config parser for workflow definitions
description:
Update internal/config/config.go to parse [workflows.*] sections from cortex.toml.

title: Extend DB schema for workflow stage tracking
description:
Add workflow stage tracking to the SQLite store (internal/store/store.go).

New table: bead_stages
- id (auto PK)
- bead_id (string)
- project (string)
- workflow (string, workflow name)
- current_stage (string, stage name)
- stage_index (int, 0-based position in workflow)
- total_stages (int)
- stage_history (JSON array of {stage, status, started_at, completed_at, dispatch_id})
- created_at, updated_at

New methods:
- InitBeadWorkflow(beadID, project, workflow, stages) - create tracking record
- GetBeadStage(beadID) - current stage info
- AdvanceStage(beadID) - move to next stage
- RecordStageCompletion(beadID, stage, dispatchID) - log stage done
- GetBeadsAtStage(project, stage) - query by stage
- IsWorkflowComplete(beadID) - all stages done?

Update dispatches table: add 'workflow' and 'stage' columns (nullable for backward compat).

Acceptance: Schema migrates cleanly, methods work, existing data unaffected

title: Implement workflow engine for stage progression
description:
Create internal/workflow/engine.go - the core workflow engine that drives beads through stages.

Engine responsibilities:
- AssignWorkflow(bead) → workflow name: match bead labels/type against workflow match rules, fall back to default workflow, return 'single-shot' if no workflows configured
- GetCurrentStage(bead) → stage definition: look up where bead is in its workflow
- ShouldDispatch(bead, stage) → bool: check if stage needs a new dispatch (not already running)
- RunGate(bead, stage) → (passed bool, output string): execute gate command if defined
- Advance(bead) → (nextStage, done): move to next stage or mark workflow complete
- HandleStageCompletion(bead, dispatch) → action: when a dispatch completes, decide next action (run gate → advance or fail)

The engine sits between the scheduler and dispatcher. The scheduler calls the engine to determine what to dispatch next for each bead.

Key design: the engine is stateless - all state lives in the DB (bead_stages table). Engine reads state, computes action, writes state.

Acceptance: Engine correctly progresses beads through multi-stage workflows, handles gate failures, integrates with store

title: Add stage-aware prompt templates
description:
Extend internal/scheduler/prompt.go to support per-stage prompt templates.

Current BuildPrompt() creates a single generic prompt. Need multiple templates:

Templates (internal/workflow/prompts.go):
- 'implement': Current default prompt (implement the task)
- 'test': Focus on writing/running tests for already-implemented code
- 'review': Review code changes, check for bugs/style/security, suggest fixes
- 'draft': Write content based on brief/outline (for content workflow)
- 'edit': Edit/improve existing content for clarity and quality
- 'publish': Format and prepare content for publication
- 'analyze': Analyze data/signals and produce structured findings
- 'validate': Check analysis against risk rules, flag concerns
- 'execute': Execute a validated action with audit trail

Each template receives the same context (bead info, workspace, acceptance criteria) but frames the task differently.

BuildPrompt signature changes: BuildPrompt(bead, workspace, stage) where stage determines template selection.

Also include stage context in prompt: 'You are at stage 2/4 (test) of the dev workflow. Previous stage (implement) was completed by agent X.'

Acceptance: Prompts render correctly per stage, backward compatible when no workflow

title: Extend role system for workflow-specific roles
description:
Extend internal/scheduler/role.go to support workflow-defined roles.

Current roles: coder, reviewer, ops (inferred from labels).

New roles needed:
- writer (content drafting)
- editor (content editing/review)
- publisher (content publishing)
- analyst (data/signal analysis)
- risk (risk validation)
- executor (action execution)
- auditor (confirmation/audit)

Changes:
- When a workflow stage specifies a role, use that role directly (no inference needed)
- Keep InferRole() as fallback for single-shot mode (no workflow)
- Agent naming: {project}-{role} remains the pattern
- Add ValidateRole() to check role is known

Acceptance: Workflow-specified roles override inferred roles, agent names resolve correctly

title: Update scheduler to drive workflow stages
description:
Modify internal/scheduler/scheduler.go RunTick to integrate the workflow engine.

Current flow: discover beads → infer role/complexity → pick provider → dispatch
New flow: discover beads → assign workflow → get current stage → check gates → infer complexity (or use stage override) → pick provider → dispatch stage

Key changes to RunTick:
1. After filtering unblocked beads, call engine.AssignWorkflow() for each
2. For workflow beads: call engine.GetCurrentStage() instead of InferRole()
3. Use stage.Role for agent resolution (not label-inferred role)
4. Use stage.Tier override if set, else DetectComplexity() as before
5. Pass stage to BuildPrompt()
6. On dispatch completion detection: call engine.HandleStageCompletion()
   - If gate passes → engine.Advance() → next tick dispatches next stage
   - If gate fails → mark stage failed, retry or escalate
7. A bead is only closed (bd close) when IsWorkflowComplete() returns true
8. Single-shot beads (no workflow match) continue working exactly as before

Acceptance: Multi-stage beads progress through workflow, single-shot beads unaffected, gates enforced

title: Add built-in workflow templates: dev, content, trading
description:
Create three built-in workflow definitions that ship with Cortex.

File: internal/workflow/builtin.go

**Dev Workflow** (default=true):
- match_labels: dev, code, feature, bug, refactor
- match_types: task, bug, feature
- Stages:
  1. implement (coder) - write the code
  2. test (reviewer, gate: 'go test ./...') - verify with tests
  3. review (reviewer, tier: premium) - code review

**Content Workflow**:
- match_labels: content, blog, docs, copy, writing
- match_types: docs
- Stages:
  1. research (analyst) - gather context and outline
  2. draft (writer) - write first draft
  3. edit (editor) - review and polish
  4. publish (publisher) - format and ship

**Trading Workflow**:
- match_labels: trade, signal, execution, position
- Stages:
  1. analyze (analyst, tier: premium) - analyze signal/opportunity
  2. validate (risk) - risk check and sizing
  3. execute (executor) - place the trade
  4. confirm (auditor) - verify execution and log

Built-ins are used when no [workflows] config exists. If config defines workflows, they override built-ins. Provide a MergeWithBuiltins() function that lets config extend rather than replace.

Acceptance: Built-in workflows available out of box, overridable via config

title: Add workflow status API endpoints
description:
Extend internal/api/api.go with workflow-related endpoints.

New endpoints:
- GET /workflows - list all defined workflows with their stages
- GET /workflows/{name} - detail view of a workflow definition
- GET /beads/{id}/workflow - current workflow state for a bead (stage, history, progress)
- GET /projects/{id}/pipeline - all beads grouped by their current workflow stage

Update existing endpoints:
- GET /status - add workflow_beads_in_progress count, beads_by_stage breakdown
- GET /metrics - add cortex_workflow_stage_duration_seconds histogram, cortex_workflow_completions_total counter

Acceptance: Endpoints return correct data, backward compatible (empty/null when no workflows)

title: Stage-based pipeline + auto-spawn teams
description: Implement stage-based role inference, stage-aware prompts, agent-busy guard, stage dispatch, auto-spawn teams, and /teams API endpoint
close_reason: Implemented stage-based pipeline with auto-spawn teams

title: Phase 2: Health & Self-Healing
description: Gateway monitoring, stuck task detection with tier escalation, zombie process cleanup, flock mutex for single-instance enforcement. Runs as separate goroutine on 2min interval.

title: Gateway health monitor
description:
Implement internal/health/health.go — monitors the OpenClaw gateway service.

Function:
- CheckGateway(unitName string) -> HealthStatus
  1. Run: systemctl --user is-active {unitName}
  2. If inactive -> attempt restart: systemctl --user restart {unitName}
  3. If restart fails -> check for stale locks/PIDs in /tmp/openclaw-gateway*, clear them, retry
  4. Record health event to store (gateway_restart type)
  5. Track restart count in rolling 1h window
  6. If 3+ restarts in 1h -> return critical status (triggers Matrix alert upstream)

Runs as separate goroutine on config.Health.CheckInterval (default 2min).

Acceptance criteria:
- Detects inactive gateway and restarts it
- Clears stale lock files on restart failure
- Records all health events to SQLite
- Escalates to alert after 3 restarts in 1h
- Unit tests mock systemctl commands
close_reason: Phase 2 health modules implemented with tests

title: Stuck task detection + tier escalation
description:
Implement internal/health/stuck.go — detects dispatched tasks that have been running too long and handles retries with tier escalation.

Function:
- CheckStuckDispatches(timeout duration, maxRetries int) -> []StuckAction
  1. Query store.GetStuckDispatches(timeout) — dispatches WHERE status=running AND dispatched_at < now()-timeout
  2. For each stuck dispatch:
     a. Check if PID is still alive (kill -0 pid)
     b. If PID dead -> mark status=failed in store
     c. If PID alive but past timeout -> kill it (SIGTERM, wait 5s, SIGKILL)
     d. If retries < maxRetries: re-dispatch with escalated tier (fast->balanced->premium)
        Set escalated_from_tier on new dispatch record
     e. If retries >= maxRetries -> mark status=failed, log, return alert action
  3. Record health events for each action taken

Acceptance criteria:
- Correctly identifies stuck dispatches past timeout
- Dead PIDs detected and cleaned up
- Alive-but-stuck PIDs killed gracefully
- Tier escalation works: fast->balanced->premium
- Stops retrying after maxRetries, flags for alert
- Unit tests with mock PID checks and store data
close_reason: Phase 2 health modules implemented with tests

title: Zombie process cleanup
description:
Implement internal/health/zombie.go — finds orphaned openclaw agent processes that have no matching dispatch record.

Function:
- CleanZombies() -> int (count killed)
  1. Run: pgrep -f 'openclaw agent' to get all PIDs running openclaw agents
  2. Query store.GetRunningDispatches() to get all tracked PIDs
  3. Any PID from pgrep NOT in the dispatches table is an orphan
  4. Kill orphans: SIGTERM, wait 5s, SIGKILL if still alive
  5. Record health event for each zombie killed (zombie_killed type)
  6. Return count of killed processes

Called from the health check goroutine on each interval.

Acceptance criteria:
- Correctly identifies orphan processes (PID exists but no dispatch record)
- Does NOT kill processes that are tracked in dispatches
- Graceful kill with SIGTERM fallback to SIGKILL
- Records health events for audit trail
- Unit tests with mock pgrep output and store data
close_reason: Phase 2 health modules implemented with tests

title: Single-instance flock mutex
description:
Add flock-based mutex to cmd/cortex/main.go so only one Cortex instance can run at a time.

On startup:
1. Open lock file at /tmp/cortex.lock (or config-specified path)
2. Attempt flock(LOCK_EX | LOCK_NB)
3. If lock fails -> log 'Another Cortex instance is running', exit 1
4. Hold lock for lifetime of process (released on exit)

Use syscall.Flock in Go.

Acceptance criteria:
- Second instance exits immediately with clear error message
- Lock released cleanly on normal exit and SIGTERM
- Unit test: start two instances, verify second fails
close_reason: Phase 2 health modules implemented with tests
